On Topic: Interesting thought about touch screen, perhaps someone on the CM board will be able to test it.
[/quote]
Hey, it’s the inside community boards, so that rules out all the newbs and n00bs. But you have a point, writing longs posts wastes too much time :)[/quote]

I don’t see it as a waste of time, especially when people post great ideas in long posts, such as recording and playback of events such as you mentioned, that is really one of the best ideas I have ever heard.

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @wL1 wL
item.description:
@wL1 wrote:

Hehe, it turned out that recording/playback was the most useful addition to my engine (ok, besides the engine itself). I was extremely useful in script debugging/development. Not only was I able do track down failures in the engine by having the scene playback in slow motion until I found the place where things went wrong (fast forward/arbitrary speed playback are your friend). I also had an easy time to implement “random events”: I just had to wait and cross fingers until one of my bots encountered an unknown event. In many cases, the recorded material was already enough to create a working counter-script. The benefit from this surpasses the effort of implementation by far. I’m surprised noone else had this idea to date.
Based on that feature, there’s much more you can think of. I had bots running remotely on some linux boxes (without x-server), so I added a neat feature to connect to those clients from my desktop computer and watch the live action of the bot. Basically all I did was streaming the recorded data as it is generated to a playback client - only upon connection there was some delay due to initial synchronization with the bot. From there you could start/stop scripts, chat, or control the char (of course actions are ignored while a script is running in order not to interfere with the engines’ mouse events).

At one point I was also thinking about making some money out of this stuff, and I even started to write a “master script” that had bots systematically generate money by directing control flow to appropriate sub-scripts. Basically all that was needed, was to think of a good (not yet used!!!) character name, register it and start the bot. From there on, I never needed to care about it again, since it autonomously did tut island, raised needed levels, etc. Ok, that was in the pre-Aryan era where people still thought such things as java bots don’t exist in “superior, unhackable” rs2, so people weren’t too suspicious
Updating was as simple as typing “mkdir client330 && cd client330 && …/updateClient && cd bot && make deploy && /somePath/launch_bots” (maybe also a “diff -ru bot/ …/client329/bot | less” to check the changes in the client).
I only found it bothersome to get rid of the money with all those scammers around, so I disposed of the idea and had the guys going just for fun. There was a time when i owned the highscores in certain skills: in one skill, like 2/3 on the first page were my chars
Anyway, I wonder how much work my engine would need in order to get going again.

I think we should have joined our effords, the results probably would have been massive.

A small note slightly OnTopic:
I wonder whether jagex considered the possibility of having a touch screen. Wouldn’t that render jagex’ mouse motion dectection mechanism totally useless?

(Edit: fixed numerous typos.)

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

Interesting. I see that you and I have something in common: Stream-of-Consciousness typing. It takes me a long time and quite a bit of editing to make my posts somewhat coherent.

That wasn’t a jab.

At any rate, I can see where you get the impression that I came across that way and it was not intentional. When I typed it, I didn’t it could have been taken any other way than the way I meant it. What I had meant was that there really is a way to inject code into the client and have it go completely unnoticed. I was assuming they don’t change anything drastic. The way I see it, all things are subject to stipulations. There are very few absolutes in life. Coding is even less certain. Of course they can detect injected code, but they would have to change something if they did. I believe I have my bases covered in that regard.

Pertaining to your question about whether I know the code enough to disengage their current graphics rendering safely: yes. I still have to work a bit more on tuning the system to run under 1% cpu constantly. My current bots run at an average of 4-8% with occasional spikes over 10.

The recording/playback feature is intriguing. Currently, though I don’t use a record/playback (though the idea sounds like something I would like to soon implement), I have a control panel that monitors all bots, the bots communicate asynchronously with the control panel and the control panel can start up, shut down, execute commands on bots, etc. My favorite part is the map that shows each and every bot as the minimap would in the game. The bots’ locations are updated in real-time. Hovering over the dots gives a tooltip with tidbits of info name/inventory items/current action/etc. Clicking on a dot will change the color of the dot and cause the bot to send small visual updates to the control panel in another pane. The update is slowish… only around 1-2 frames per second but it allows the random ethnic individual that is being paid peanuts to keep track of what the bot is doing visually. I’m thinking that I’ll be able to throw the record/playback functionality without too much pain.

Concerning why I do this. It is similar to your reasons for doing it. I started out just interested in tinkering with the game. I had just left diablo 2 hacking and got bored during some downtime at work. My reasons have changed since then, the only reason I continue to do it is for money.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @wL1 wL
item.description:
@wL1 wrote:

semaphore:

There is nothing wrong with editing the client, as long as you know what you are doing. Anyone that says otherwise, is just really saying that they don’t know how to do it right.

I cannot agree with that in either case.
Editing the client is possible and not too hard if you have enough experience and patience. I followed this sheme for a very long time, basically it was my only way of doing things. But one could aswell state that “There is nothing wrong with packet sending, as long as you know what you are doing”. Ok, not really a good comparison due to the greatly increased complexity of latter approach. I mean, your statement implies that there are no other ways, maybe even better. What happens if jagex decides one day to recode their protection or even just introduces a new trap. Do you go through the code every time to check what they have done? Maybe your system is good enough that there’s only very few situations where engine interferes with the client and in the worst case it will just not work anymore.
Wouldn’t it be great to have an universal engine that would plug into any client, insensitive to any protection mechanisms that are coded around the client core. Of course, such a system will not survive a (partial) rewrite of the client (like rs -> rs2). Still, refraining from direct interference with the client will avoid a lot of hassle with traps and other protections put into place. I’m not saying such a sheme is trivial or even realistic to implement, but if I ever will come back to this again my research is surely going into this direction.
Anyway, as mentioned I followed the former way for a long time and things started to get boring and cumbersome at one point. I had very robust routines and almost fully automated updating mechanism, basically I only had to manully go through the diff between clients and now and then required treatment of some “special packets”. My system required this due to the nice features it had. For example it had a no-graphics mode which lowered CPU usage to ~1% even on moderate machines (Athlon 700Mhz). Maybe you know the code good enough such that you know which trap in the rendering code I’m talking about.
Just saying, eventually it’s a good idea to try some new concepts. At least for me, I’m not doing this to get “useless stuff”, but in order to learn something, try “something”, just to see what happens. I always enjoyed using my engine to send out my creations into the virtual world in order to do something interesting and the excitement when checking your log files the next day and to see what funny situations they were involved in I even had a nice recording/playback system coded in (which actually is rather trivial to implement - just overide the stream class to dump the incoming data and also store some meta data for proper synchronisation and if you whish also the user input) and I still have GBs of records on some backup disks. Afaik 1Mb gives you about 2h 100% accurate playback with camera movement and mouse motion/clicks.
To summarize, this is (was) my way of playing runescape :)))

PS: Sorry for having nothing to say ontopic

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

here is my latest Tester class, it has worked great for me so far, very visual compared to a bunch of printlns, and it can be run as an applet or application:

import javax.swing.*;
import java.applet.Applet;
import java.awt.*;
import java.awt.event.*;

public class Tester extends Applet implements KeyListener, MouseListener, MouseMotionListener, FocusListener {

    public boolean mL, mML, kL, fL;

    public int width = 400;
    public int height = 400;
    public int x, y;
    String s = "";
    String focus = "";

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        JFrame.setDefaultLookAndFeelDecorated(true);
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("Tester");
        frame.setResizable(false);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        Tester tester = new Tester();
        tester.init();
        frame.add(tester);
        frame.setSize(400, 400);
        frame.setVisible(true);
    }

    public void init() {
        System.out.println("To toggle listeners on and off:
F1 : MouseListener
F2 : MouseMotionListener
F3 : KeyListener
F4 : FocusListener
");
        setSize(width, height);
        x = width / 2;
        y = height / 2;
        setBackground(Color.black);
        addMouseListener(this);
        addMouseMotionListener(this);
        addKeyListener(this);
        addFocusListener(this);

        //mL = true;
        //mML = true;
        //kL = true;
        //fL = true;
    }

    private void msg_mL(String s) {
        if (mL)
            System.out.println(s);
    }

    private void msg_mML(String s) {
        if (mML)
            System.out.println(s);
    }

    private void msg_kL(String s) {
        if (kL)
            System.out.println(s);
    }

    private void msg_fL(String s) {
        if (fL)
            System.out.println(s);
    }

    public void mousePressed(MouseEvent evt) {
        msg_mL("MouseEvent(Component source, MouseEvent.MOUSE_PRESSED , " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + MouseEvent.getMouseModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getX() + ", " + evt.getY() + ", " + evt.getClickCount() + ", " + evt.isPopupTrigger() + ", " + evt.getButton() + ");");
    }

    public void mouseReleased(MouseEvent evt) {
        msg_mL("MouseEvent(Component source, MouseEvent.MOUSE_RELEASED, " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + MouseEvent.getMouseModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getX() + ", " + evt.getY() + ", " + evt.getClickCount() + ", " + evt.isPopupTrigger() + ", " + evt.getButton() + ");");
    }

    public void mouseClicked(MouseEvent evt) {
        msg_mL("MouseEvent(Component source, MouseEvent.MOUSE_CLICKED , " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + MouseEvent.getMouseModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getX() + ", " + evt.getY() + ", " + evt.getClickCount() + ", " + evt.isPopupTrigger() + ", " + evt.getButton() + ");
");
        x = evt.getX();
        y = evt.getY();
        s = "";
        repaint();
        evt.consume();
    }

    public void mouseEntered(MouseEvent evt) {
        msg_mL("MouseEvent(Component source, MouseEvent.MOUSE_ENTERED, " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + MouseEvent.getMouseModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getX() + ", " + evt.getY() + ", " + evt.getClickCount() + ", " + evt.isPopupTrigger() + ", " + evt.getButton() + ");
");
    }

    public void mouseExited(MouseEvent evt) {
        msg_mL("MouseEvent(Component source, MouseEvent.MOUSE_EXITED, " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + MouseEvent.getMouseModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getX() + ", " + evt.getY() + ", " + evt.getClickCount() + ", " + evt.isPopupTrigger() + ", " + evt.getButton() + ");
");
    }

    public void mouseDragged(MouseEvent evt) {
        msg_mML("MouseEvent(Component source, MouseEvent.MOUSE_DRAGGED" + ", " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + MouseEvent.getMouseModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getX() + ", " + evt.getY() + ", " + evt.getClickCount() + ", " + evt.isPopupTrigger() + ", " + evt.getButton() + ");");
    }

    public void mouseMoved(MouseEvent evt) {
        msg_mML("MouseEvent(Component source, MouseEvent.MOUSE_MOVED" + ", " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + MouseEvent.getMouseModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getX() + ", " + evt.getY() + ", " + evt.getClickCount() + ", " + evt.isPopupTrigger() + ", " + evt.getButton() + ");");
        x = evt.getX();
        y = evt.getY();
        repaint();
        evt.consume();
    }

    public void keyPressed(KeyEvent evt) {
        msg_kL("KeyEvent(Component source, KeyEvent.KEY_PRESSED, " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + KeyEvent.getKeyModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getKeyCode() + "[" + KeyEvent.getKeyText(evt.getKeyCode()) + "], " + evt.getKeyChar() + ");");
        int i = evt.getKeyCode();
        if (i == KeyEvent.VK_F1)
            mL = !mL;
        else if (i == KeyEvent.VK_F2)
            mML = !mML;
        else if (i == KeyEvent.VK_F3)
            kL = !kL;
        else if (i == KeyEvent.VK_F4)
            fL = !fL;
        else if (i == KeyEvent.VK_ENTER) {
            s = "";
            repaint();
        }

        char c = evt.getKeyChar();
        if (c != KeyEvent.CHAR_UNDEFINED) {
            s = s + c;
            repaint();
            evt.consume();
        }
    }

    public void keyReleased(KeyEvent evt) {
        msg_kL("KeyEvent(Component source, KeyEvent.KEY_RELEASED, " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + KeyEvent.getKeyModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getKeyCode() + "[" + KeyEvent.getKeyText(evt.getKeyCode()) + "], " + evt.getKeyChar() + ");
");
    }

    public void keyTyped(KeyEvent evt) {
        msg_kL("KeyEvent(Component source, KeyEvent.KEY_TYPED, " + evt.getWhen() + ", " + evt.getModifiers() + "[" + KeyEvent.getKeyModifiersText(evt.getModifiers()) + "], " + evt.getKeyCode() + "[" + KeyEvent.getKeyText(evt.getKeyCode()) + "], " + evt.getKeyChar() + ");");
    }

    public void focusGained(FocusEvent evt) {
        msg_fL("FocusEvent(Component source, FocusEvent.FOCUS_GAINED, " + evt.isTemporary() + ");");
        focus = "GAINED, temp: " + evt.isTemporary();
        repaint();
    }

    public void focusLost(FocusEvent evt) {
        msg_fL("FocusEvent(Component source, FocusEvent.FOCUS_LOST, " + evt.isTemporary() + ");");
        focus = "LOST, temp: " + evt.isTemporary();
        repaint();
    }

    public void paint(Graphics g) {
        g.setColor(Color.gray);
        g.drawLine(x, y, x, y - 10);
        g.drawLine(x, y, x + 10, y);
        g.setColor(Color.green);
        g.drawString(x + "," + y, x - 20, y - 15);
        g.setColor(Color.orange);
        g.drawString(s, x + 2, y - 2);
        g.setColor(Color.yellow);
        g.drawString(focus, 1, 15);
    }
}

Read full topic

[quote=“Miss Silabsoft, post:35, topic:23620”]just out of curiousity what causes the difference between a emulated mouse click and a real one why do they show up differently?[/quote]It all depends how you go about emulating it, for Krichevskoy’s code example, you define a method that returns an array of MouseEvent, which will then be sent to whatever is handling the events. If you write a decent enough method, it should be somewhat identical to a real click

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

[quote=“moparisthebest, post:30, topic:23620”]Yes, the default mouse path algorithm I use is benland’s splines, edited to suit my needs. But the reason I thought it was good is any applet you don’t have to worry about detection on, perhaps like RSC, or cannons or something, you would just want to use a straight line path (or no path at all for that matter).

Eventually I will implement something that queries specific system values and puts them in some sort of algorithm that will set specific random values for each hardware set up, It isn’t that far along yet though ;)[/quote]
or no path.

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Yes, the default mouse path algorithm I use is benland’s splines, edited to suit my needs. But the reason I thought it was good is any applet you don’t have to worry about detection on, perhaps like RSC, or cannons or something, you would just want to use a straight line path (or no path at all for that matter).

Eventually I will implement something that queries specific system values and puts them in some sort of algorithm that will set specific random values for each hardware set up, It isn’t that far along yet though

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

moparisthebest:

Krichevskoy, back on topic, I am implementing this class, heavily edited, into my bot, and in doing so I have discovered a flaw in it, printing out the mouseevents of your class with a click count of 2 just sends one set of mouse events

Well, I could act like I know what I’m doing and say that the intended usage is

emu.clickLeft(x,y);
emu.setClickCount(2);
emu.clickLeft(x,y);

but that would be stupid and, honestly, I wasn’t thinking about usage at all when I added the click count setter - I just thought “Hey, a variable. That needs some public access.”

moparisthebest:

edit: oh, and just let me say that your idea of allowing each script/user to specify and use their own mouse algorithm is ingenious, it is already implemented in my bot, thanks for the awesome suggestion ;D

Thanks
That, too, was something I thought of in the thirty seconds before I posted - actually I haven’t designed anything that far in advance of myself. However, it would allow scripters to use whatever level of mouse pathing they are competent enough to create (I’m sure that some stock implementations of, say, cubic splines would be written soon enough for anyone else). If the scripter himself uses an open design, particularly concerned people might be able to generate their own average-behaviour pathing equations or add in little quirks that they’ve noticed in their actual mouse movements.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Krichevskoy, back on topic, I am implementing this class, heavily edited, into my bot, and in doing so I have discovered a flaw in it, printing out the mouseevents of your class with a click count of 2 just sends one set of mouse events, like this:

mousePressed: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_PRESSED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,extModifiers=Button1,clickCount=2] on panel0
mouseReleased: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_RELEASED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=2] on panel0
mouseClicked: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_CLICKED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=2] on panel0

but if you double click on the window manually with a real mouse, you get this:

mousePressed: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_PRESSED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,extModifiers=Button1,clickCount=1] on panel0
mouseReleased: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_RELEASED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=1] on panel0
mouseClicked: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_CLICKED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=1] on panel0
mousePressed: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_PRESSED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,extModifiers=Button1,clickCount=2] on panel0
mouseReleased: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_RELEASED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=2] on panel0
mouseClicked: java.awt.event.MouseEvent[MOUSE_CLICKED,(649,253),button=1,modifiers=Button1,clickCount=2] on panel0

so unless you were planning on sending a two in a row of these you need to implement a simple for loop.

When I get this class done I will post it, well the whole bot will be open source, so w/e

edit: oh, and just let me say that your idea of allowing each script/user to specify and use their own mouse algorithm is ingenious, it is already implemented in my bot, thanks for the awesome suggestion ;D

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

I disagree completely. I can see how most would think that way though. Code Injection, when done improperly, can be very dangerous. But, doing it right, is safe as any of the other ‘methodology’ this community endorses.

There is nothing wrong with editing the client, as long as you know what you are doing. Anyone that says otherwise, is just really saying that they don’t know how to do it right.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Emulation
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“frank_, post:22, topic:23620”][quote author=moparisthebest link=topic=35924.msg435395#msg435395 date=1163220597]

As for input solutions, if you make a bot i can provide input.

But will this involve overriding any classes in the runtime library? because I don’t think anyone wants that…
[/quote]
Why are you so dead-set about not patching the runtime classes?[/quote]

It is just the type of thing that you never want to do if it is at all humanly possible to avoid, it would be frowned upon by most programmers.
